G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under G.L. c. 208, § 28, which provides that custody and parenting time orders may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and when such modification serves the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Rachel Bennett, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20 for a Modification of Custody and Parenting Time Order entered by this Court on April 15, 2019, concerning the parties’ minor child, Ethan Bennett (age 8).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 7.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court under G.L. c. 208, § 7, as both parties reside in Bristol County and the original Judgment of Custody issued from this Court.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that stability and the child’s best interests control any modification determination.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case, not a general modification-of-custody standard case, and it does not state that “stability and the child’s best interests control any modification determination” or that Massachusetts courts have *consistently* so held. It discusses that removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 requires a showing that relocation is in the child’s best interests, and in the shared-custody context emphasizes best interests and maintenance of relationships with both parents—not stability as a controlling principle for all modifications. Thus it cannot fairly be cited for the broad proposition about all modification determinations.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “‘The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), citing Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976)… ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that stability and the child’s best interests control any modification determination.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The case concerns an initial divorce judgment involving custody and removal, not a modification proceeding. While the court repeatedly emphasizes that the children’s best interests are paramount, it does not state that “stability” and best interests control any modification determination, nor does it discuss standards governing later modifications of existing orders. Thus it cannot be cited as authority for Massachusetts courts consistently holding that stability and the child’s best interests control modification determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important.”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: The best interests of the child standard governs all custody determinations.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The case clearly states that the governing principle in custody cases is the welfare (best interests) of the child, but it does so in the context of a particular custody dispute, not as a universal statement that this standard governs all custody determinations in every context. It affirms the welfare-of-the-child standard as the controlling consideration in such cases, but does not purport to address or resolve every possible type of custody determination. Thus it supports a narrower proposition (that the welfare of the child is the controlling standard in custody decisions of this kind), not the broad "all custody determinations" claim.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: "The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule." We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939), and added: "In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration."

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The best interests of the child standard governs all custody determinations.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion reaffirms that the best interests of the child is the governing standard for custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and more generally describes it as the long‑standing custody standard in Massachusetts. However, it does not state that this standard governs *all* custody determinations without exception; it expressly notes that different standards (e.g., substantial change in circumstances under § 20 for modifications) can apply in related contexts. Thus it supports the centrality of the best-interests test in initial custody awards, not the absolutist "all custody determinations" formulation.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. … [T]he ‘best interests of the child’ standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation.’”

Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).proposition: Where both parents are fit and a new arrangement better accommodates the developmental stage and schooling of the child, modification has been found appropriate.
Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).support_reasoning: The case does involve modification of custody in light of changed circumstances, but the court’s focus is not on accommodating the child’s developmental stage or schooling where both parents are equally fit. Instead, the modification rested on the father’s relocation to Colorado, the child no longer being in a settled home, and the mother’s demonstrated ability to offer a stable, established home. The opinion does not frame the decision as a balancing of two fit parents based on the child’s developmental needs or schooling, so it does not directly support the specific proposition stated.
Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).relevant_excerpt: “Manifestly there was a relevant change of circumstances (Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191) adequate to support a change in the order for custody. There was strong assurance of the mother’s ability to offer a good home and the daughter was no longer in a settled home. … In the new circumstances of the parents it was not an unreasonable conclusion that the daughter would be better off in the libellant’s family.”

Bodwell v. Brooks, 148 Mass. App. Ct. 10.raw_text: Bodwell v. Brooks, 148 Mass. App. Ct. 103 (2019)
Bodwell v. Brooks, 148 Mass. App. Ct. 10.proposition: Where both parents are fit and a new arrangement better accommodates the developmental stage and schooling of the child, modification has been found appropriate.

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: The Court’s primary inquiry is the welfare and happiness of the child, not the convenience of the parents.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the statutory and common-law standard that removal is decided based on the child’s best interests, and it emphasizes that those interests are closely interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent. The court does not articulate a general hierarchy that the child’s welfare and happiness are primary over the parents’ convenience; instead, it expressly requires that the custodial parent’s interests and advantages of the move be considered as part of the best-interests analysis. Thus, it does not clearly stand for the proposition that the court’s primary inquiry is only the child’s welfare rather than any parental convenience.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt:
We consider that factor not in itself conclusive. The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent, and the determination, therefore, requires that the interests of the mother also be taken into account.
...
We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: In determining the existence of a material change, courts may consider maturation of the child, improved living conditions of a parent, and the child’s evolving needs.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is an appeal from an initial custody judgment, not a post‑judgment modification case, and it does not discuss the standard for finding a “material change” in circumstances. The Court focuses on the required findings regarding domestic violence, the effect on the child, and the statutory requirement of written findings when a 209A order exists. While the Court briefly notes the passage of time and that the child is now older, that comment goes only to what the judge may consider on remand, not to defining or applying a material‑change standard, nor to improved living conditions or evolving needs as factors in that standard.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above. … As almost three years have gone by since the Probate Court issued its judgment and Vaughn is now almost fourteen years of age, it may be appropriate for the judge to interview the child again as to his preference and for the judge to evaluate the success of the stipulated custody arrangement the parties have been living under in the interim.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: In determining the existence of a material change, courts may consider maturation of the child, improved living conditions of a parent, and the child’s evolving needs.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion is about choosing between two adoptive placements based on the child’s best interests, not about modifying an existing custody or visitation order upon a ‘material change in circumstances.’ The court does discuss Hugo’s age, developmental progress, special needs, and the prospective caregivers’ ability to address those needs, but it never frames this in terms of determining whether there has been a material change. Thus, it does not clearly establish the specific legal principle that courts may consider maturation, improved living conditions, and evolving needs in a material-change analysis.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development. The judge also took into account whether Hugo’s present home itself will provide a stable environment for him.

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).proposition: In determining the existence of a material change, courts may consider maturation of the child, improved living conditions of a parent, and the child’s evolving needs.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).support_reasoning: The opinion is about the constitutionality and construction of a grandparent visitation statute and does not concern modification of prior custody or visitation orders based on a ‘material change’ standard. The court’s analysis focuses on presumptive parental rights, harm to the child, and best-interests standards in the context of third‑party visitation, not on considering changes such as child maturation, improved parental living conditions, or evolving needs as a material change. Thus it does not support the claimed proposition.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).relevant_excerpt: “The statute adopts the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the test for determining visitation… To accord with due process, an evaluation of the best interests of the child under the statute requires that a parental decision concerning grandparent visitation be given presumptive validity… To succeed, the grandparents must allege and prove that the failure to grant visitation will cause the child significant harm by adversely affecting the child’s health, safety, or welfare.”

Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).proposition: Where both parents are fit and a new arrangement better accommodates the developmental stage and schooling of the child, modification has been found appropriate.
Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).support_reasoning: The court does approve a modification of custody based on changed circumstances and a judgment that the child would be better off in the mother’s home, but the opinion does not frame the decision in terms of both parents being equally fit or in terms of better accommodating the child’s developmental stage or schooling. Instead, the focus is on the father’s removal of the child from Massachusetts, the loss of a settled home, and the mother’s now-stable home environment. The proposition overstates and reframes the holding in developmental-stage/schooling terms that the opinion itself does not emphasize.
Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).relevant_excerpt: “Manifestly there was a relevant change of circumstances (Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191) adequate to support a change in the order for custody. There was strong assurance of the mother’s ability to offer a good home and the daughter was no longer in a settled home. … In the new circumstances of the parents it was not an unreasonable conclusion that the daughter would be better off in the libellant’s family.”
